kzu-Y548AzBRC0B09PDT7g.text: I like the hard rock cafe. The food is great, there are always large portions. Its great for crowds of people for a party, wouldnt recommend it for a romantic meal though. The cocktails are also very good, and the prices are quite reasonable. They have a shop there which sells t-shirts, key rings etc also. but these things are rather pricy.  The food is mainly burgers, nachos, american stuff. They have guitars up on the walls from famous people.

JCqmfOWNPfH6JWpz6EKUrg.text: Everything in here is pretty standard....typical American style, typical music-memorabilia, typical HUGE portions etc etc. I came here once having a hankering for a hamburger, but I found the layers and layers of meat, lettuce, cheese, bacon and bread too much to handle. I ordered the BBQ Burger but I couldn't eat half of it. The chips too, were all left on my plate.  Ok, I admit it probably has something to do with the fact that I had cheese and coriander quesadilla to share with my friends to start with, but I only had 2 slices, and I was starving. I must admit though  - the quesadilla was delicious. The burger...not so much. As I was munching my way through I kept thinking about my mum - if there was something that wasn't particularly tasty she would say to me 'it's not worth the calories Em!' , and she was right.  Overall I wasn't impressed with my burger, but the quesadilla was amazing. The entire time I was there, more and more people came in (particularly, and somewhat ironically, mostly American tourists) and all ordered ribs and wings.  To be honest I found it difficult to have a conversation with my friends whilst in Hard Rock because the music was blaring, but the decor was quite cool and the seats were comfy!

gIe4uBwqkZgP-zqd53xUzw.text: Hard Rock Cafe Edinburgh 20 George Street Edinburgh EH2-2PH, Scotland Telephone: 44-131-260-3000 hardrock.com For the super hungry tummy and whoever likes it large. A bit tasteless but who cares with all that great music and almost singing staff. At the end of the day, this is a place you go for the fantastic atmosphere.

U6Z_bDD_ievDtVZx4OzmNA.text: I have friends who are devotees of this restaurant, but to me the food is very overpriced for what it is; standard 'American' fare. Really, the menu choices are fairly uninspiring. On the plus side the cocktails are grand but if you're going to spend 6-7 on a brightly coloured fruity alcoholic drink on George Street then you're better wandering to a custom built cocktail bar such as Candy or Tonic.

VWZDXM5fGqRr8ikrD7msdQ.text: good food and lots of it but its a bit expensive   gift shop is good though

z0AV3Y4uuFno9VuGF9fvpQ.text: very busy, very corporate... the food was a disappointment really as HRC is usually better on the occasions when i have been to one.. service was good but i won't be rushing back... might learn how to make pulled pork myself instead for an annual fix   still, everyones heard of it and i guess we all like a bit of familiarity

kNeFbeiQAc5FmtuxSyENAg.text: This restaurant is likely one of the loudest on George Street. It is always bustling and the staff wear the shortest of shorts! I love it here as you always get consistency with your food and drink which can be so rare in restaurants. The prices are a little above average but nothing out of the ordinary for George Street. If you go and like pork you have to try the Pig Sandwich! It is amazing!

Z5Rhu1HZP8HgjmlbLsgMuw.text: I think the main problem with the Har dRock cafe is that it hasn't evolved over the years. It still has this very eighties feel but not in a retro tongue in cheek kind of way, it actually means it. I know it was probably a huge kick to go there when it opened but it just does not live up to expecations or the prices it charges for its food. You get a really basic plate of nachos or a club sandwich for about 8 and you can't help feeling that you would have been better off staying at home and making your own.

TylnWWWyKDvBF7ceIkh3cg.text: Great place to take the kids as staff are great with them. Food is very good and drinks not too expensive considering on George Street. Some great music memorabilia as you would expect.

U8edrYfDApArCYNU9CYsUg.text: Went with children during the Festival as everywhere is so busy. Wish we hadn't  the burger was disgusting like canteen food and the service poor. Advised the waiter and he acknowledged it but thats all ! Lesson learnt  dont go to overpriced couldn't care less chain restaurants

NNwET8vV8x-ocaJPRy9kFQ.text: Although this establishment is definitely on the pricey side  beware of the service charge! It is definitely worth a visit if you've never been. The atmosphere is great, the food is delicious and served in large portions and the cocktails are brightly coloured and inventive. What more could you ask for?   Actually, on that note they're not particularly good at checking the toilets before they close up. A friend of mine once went in to use the toilet and fell asleep, when she woke up she was trapped inside as they had locked up for the night! Thankfully a few phone calls later she was let out, but just be careful to stay conscious in the toilets :P

1rJ9GB3kFctRkhV32pYocw.text: Nice place and staff! This is a must visit for me whenever I am in Edinburgh. Love the salads and cocktails!

C0JUgmrq8h-R7SzkodQWNg.text: I have always loved the Hard Rock Cafe concept and wanted to take my kids there, but having previously visited those in London and Orlando, Edinburgh somewhat paled in comparison. Some of the memorabilia is amusingly bargain basement - Gidget Gein's bass, a White Zombie guitar! That said it has a fun atmosphere and you can let your hair down there. The food is alright though, and plenty of it too, with friendly enough service.

jFEGRmuZe5fwCugyZnBmyg.text: It s always a  pleasure to eat and stay at  a  hard rock cafe!  Event if this is a really  small one, I had a great and pleasant experience

6DXqtBcjmknsGx34jx52BA.text: I have been to a few Hard Rock Cafe in the States and elsewhere.  However, this is by far the worse when it comes to food.  The atmosphere and music are about the same as every other Hard Rock Cafe everywhere.  Great waitresses / waiter with great personalities & awesome music as always.  But the main course here is just not up to scratch.  I came here on 2 separate occasions and I had a big plate of Nachos to share for starters which was great.  However, when it came to main course, I found my burger meat very dry and tough. I stopped eating halfway through.  It was the same last time when I came here for the ribs.  Again they were quite dry and only ate halfway through as it was unpleasant to eat really dry meat.  Our burgers came straight after they took away our empty Nacho plate so maybe timing need to be adjusted a little as it gives the impression that our food has been long cooked waiting at the counter for us to finish our starters.  I think they need to get back to basics and ensure the meat are properly cooked to juicy succulent standard.  Lebowskis and Holyrood 9A have better burgers.

SMcvryzxxEBd-oAAfU8NWw.text: Against other eateries on a food-to-food basis, this is a three star, BUT, they don't have the acres of rock memorabilia and the fun wait staff that Hard Rock has. We travel quite a bit, and once a trip or so we get the urge for slightly more familiar food. The menu is the same for the most part, with a haggis add-on for the Scots but overall it's as American as rock-n-roll's roots, even if it was started in the UK and the Seminole Tribe owns the chain... But I digress.  Get some potato skins, dear Scots. Have a Long Island Ice Tea, and, if you can bear spicy, get a good ol' Red White and Bleu burger!

photos.caption: Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Scott Ian guitar (Anthrax)

bAZ2osHm2h-EbBqj1glZQA.text: After a fun afternoon chasing my friend's toddler around the big amazing park in the Meadows, we were feeling pretty hungry. As my pal is very picky, and bambinos aren't welcome everywhere, we decided to pop down to George Street and the HRC. I'm not sure why I agreed to it, because the handful of times I've been I've found the food to be distinctly sub-par but I thought maybe I was just ordering the wrong things.  First up: service. Friendly: but very, very, slow. It took a while for the waitress to take our drinks order, another while for the grown ups drinks to arrive (Pepsi of course, we were in charge of a wee one), and another five minutes for the little one's apple juice.    It was quite difficult to stop him stealing his mum's Pepsi, before his juice arrived; running around causing chaos is thirsty work!  For the mains, Sarah had ordered the twisted mac and cheese as usual. I decided to go for the pulled pork sandwich because I've heard the pulled pork in HRC is dead good and I'd recently eaten a fabulous pulled pork bun at the Bread Street Brasserie that I hadn't stopped thinking about since.  Of course, this took ages to arrive too. Cue wee man looking at the tables around us and shouting "MMMM!" (his way of saying "that looks tasty, feed me") before jamming a yellow crayon into his mouth that his mother then had to fish out. Ah the joys of parenthood.  Unfortunately for me (but happily for my waistline) the pulled pork simply wasn't up to scratch. It was dry and bland, and I choked down half of it before waving the white flag. The chips (sorry, fries) weren't that great either, totally average, and very dry.  We weren't offered ketchup, and our waitress did a speedy disappearing act after dropping our plates on the table so I wasn't able to ask her for any.  I mean it wasn't the worst meal I've had in my life, but since I've been a handful of times before and always left disappointed I'll take this as a sign that I shouldn't go back in a hurry. Or ever. The presentation and preparation of the food doesn't justify the price, either.  There are so many better places to eat on George Street, never mind Edinburgh. Give this gimicky tourist trap a wide berth.   Unless you're in for the cocktails: now there's a different story...

KKA6uc6lf_j8NZdGO9SXLA.text: I don't normally mind the Hard Rock Cafe at all, but this location was bad.  Food was blah.  Service was slow.  Food took FOREVER to come out.  Very overpriced and this place should be skipped.

NRaywz-UJ5q87NGGShgX4Q.text: I had just arrived fresh off the train from Motherwell and ready to start the party for my friend's hen do. We were to collect keys for an apartment we had booked for the weekend. It was a tad too early so we wanted to have a spot of lunch to kill time and somewhere close enough to get the keys later.  I remembered that there was a Hard Rock Cafe was nearby. I kept calling it the Solid Rock Cafe, you can guess what I was thinking about, anyway they knew what I meant.  It looked pretty quiet which we were quite happy at as we still had our suitcases with us.   The staff were brilliant and very accomodating, they took our suitcases and stored them behind the shop counter to look after them for us. The two staff members who greeted us were very pleasant and managed to get us a table for 7 adding another place setting.  The staff who served us as well were spot on and very nice, good banter.  The food was amazing but just too big a portion but then it is an American restaurant. I have been to a Hard Rock Cafe before in Barcelona so I knew the food would be good and I knew the typical style of the restaurant. So I was disappointed with lots of guitars and music memorabillia on all the walls of the restaurant. I loved the drum symbol lights. It's all in the detail you know.  Well non of us could finish our meal well except for our Winnie, she's  bottomless pit me thinks. When the bill came though it was a tad more than we'd like to have paid for. So it was a bit of eep moment but hey we agreed 'how often do you do this?'. A one off treat!  So I would recommend the Hard Rock Cafe as a place to visit as a treat.

bor_HU96TaKk5f22Xec19w.text: Went to the Hard Rock Cafe today, not the kind of place I would normally go to but my friend has a young daughter so we where left with view options in the area..  I ordered a '' Legendary Burger'' and to my surprise it was much better than I had expected!!  Children like it here and they have an interactive wall to keep the kids busy.  Only negative was the constant upselling by the staff, i wush they would have left us alone a bit more..  Don't forget to order Onion rings!!!

mixGgStl4S5_cwBnrE0OZg.text: When it comes to food, the food is average. It's a better than a lot of HRC cafes.  I enjoyed the Mac & Cheese, and to my surprise there were a lot of locals here. Usually, you see a lot of tourist in HRC.   A nice place to meet a few friends and listen to music. Drinks are a little pricey.

Jjggw16ASZDu-JWw3ypzWw.text: It's easy to sneer at The Hard Rock Cafe. It brings out an instinctive reaction of "overpriced", "soulless" and "naff" amongs those that don't know what they're talking about. It does indeed come with a few annoyances, but the rack of ribs and BBQ chicken plater I had the other night was, in it's own way, as delicious and satisfying a feast as I've had in a long time. Likewise, E-Bot's burger was a definite 10/10 for presentation, and not far behind when it came to taste.  I did feel a little sorry for the poor girl serving us though, who had clearly been told to upsell appetisers, desserts and all the various rock tat available in the shop. You could tell she didn't really want to, but I expect the unscrupulous owners gave her, or the ther staff little choice in that matter.  All in all though, it was an excellent meal, made even better by the slightly comical situation at the table next to us. What could best be described as a 30 year old teenager, complete with surf dude beads and baggy shorts, was sitting with having a meal with his parents. Snippets of the conversation along the lines of "Come on now son, is it not time to get a job? I hear the bank are recruiting" could be heard alongside the incessent hair metal soundtrack. I didn't manage to catch the lad's reaction, but I've a feeling he'd rather have had another gap year discovering himself (and transvestite prostitutes) in Thialand or Vietnam.

L9lgu2SO8ri5gk4Iak-Dxg.text: It's quite gimmicky, you always know what to expect and there are never really any surprises thrown in and it's a guarantee that the food is going to be top notch! My burger of choice is always the BBQ Bacon Cheeseburger it's just so good!   The walls are adorned with lots of musical memorabilia to give you lots to look at when enjoying your meal. Worldwide the Hard Rock Cafe have over 70,000 instruments on the walls of their restaurants which is the biggest and most valuable collection in the world. Wow.  During my years at High School I came to the Hard Rock Cafe pretty much every year for my birthday party and most of my friends did the same, I'm surprised I'm not sick of the place. My friends and I always found the fillings in the burgers funny and you will often find  slice of tomato or onion ring the size of a small childs head. On one occasion I remember my friend took an onion ring home because she found it so funny, to be fair we were only around 13 and hey, simple minds simple pleasures, I guess.  If you do go for a birthday party the staff will be more than happy to sing a rather embarrassing Happy Birthday to you and present you with a cake or a huge ice-cream sundae. The ice-cream sundaes are phenomenal but I'd recommend getting one to share if you want to fit through the door on your way out. Hard Rock Cafe is fun, great for families, smalls or large groups and is always a great option if you're looking for a hearty burger. I'm a fan!

eBqUwdfm-IVnwQpNXQ_4pA.text: I only went once in this edinburgh hard rock cafe! i was having a trip with my family around north Scotland when we stopped by edinburgh and decided to have lunch to this famous restaurant! As soon as we put our feet into it the staff was very kind and when we sat at the table we started order. I had a caesar salad which was the best i ever had. Hamburgers were also delicious!

tZ3bcMdqD6I83I7wJDrrdg.text: I'm such a fickle creature. The mere act of recently eating an awesome burger with the best, buttery mushrooms, prime beef, and two different types of melted cheese smothered all over the whole shebang, has made me instantly one star more favourable towards HRC in Edinburgh.   I still think there are other Hard Rocks with better venue space, and I still find the Hard Rock in Edinburgh slightly too low in the ceiling department, and perhaps a bit dim lighting wise, but I think I'm probably just being really persnickety.  All round, my most recent experience here was a rock n' roll themed food indulgence of banterful magnitude, and I realised I'd missed those huge long island iced teas and mojitos. I think the nachos we ordered at the beginning were probably unnecessary, considering we all had massive burgers coming, however guacamole, plus sour cream, plus cheese, plus crispy nachos, equals calorific joy.

GocsokKOEkzerx2KI4ErBQ.text: I went on Saturday for a late lunch. On the plus side the cocktails were good and the food was passable. But what I object to is the staff. Don't get me wrong the service isn't bad and they are not rude. On the contary. When I go out I dont want those who serve me to become my best friend, I don't want to tell them what I have bought whilst shopping. I dont want them to sit at my table to discuss my order. I really, really don't want them to poke me as thay walk by to and ask if everything is ok.   I know that this is how they are trained and that they are asked to mimic the " friendly American way". However please remember that we are British and that we actually prefer the British stand offishness of our waiters and waitresses. Oh and please remember that not everyone wants to Have a nice day

C-Q8We-MwEhuHCI63paafw.text: Hard Rock Cafe. You know what to expect. It's one of those chain's that everyone likes to turn their nose up at, but it actually does it's job pretty well. If you have ever been on holiday in any major city in the world, you will no doubt have come across Hard Rock.   The staff in this branch are always really friendly and helpful. They always seem to be Australian, this baffles me Australians leaving their sunny paradise for cold Scotland, but each to their own. Hard Rock is great for a group or a date. They do great burgers and big fatty sandwiches, as well as the usual American type food. I love their desserts, purely because they are huge and full of things which are bad for you but taste oh so good. Give me a Sundae and I will love you forever.  Occasionaly (special occasions, such as pay day) my flatmate and I will come in here for cocktails. He seems to spend his life going to various cocktail bars in Edinburgh and seems to think the best cocktails are to be found here. I agree they are very good. The whole experience ends up being very expensive though.

B5k-9iZb6WKu3k1kRnWZAg.text: A good addition to the HRC worldwide collection of restaurants...   HRC Edinburgh is pretty par compared with other HRCs. Depending on how busy it is the service quality and speed can vary wildly - but if you love your burgers and you can't help but buy a HRC glass from every restaurant you visit (that would include me), then it's worth a visit.   The "Twisted Mac and Cheese" side order (for 4.95) was really small, so if you're thinking of going for that as a main meal you might want to think again...   No lunchtime specials or anything like that but the waiter did ask if I had any discounts/vouchers when going for the bill. Beware of 10/15% service charge added to all totals over 30!

V0q9GtiKO3PwST1B2evGjg.text: This is not a restaurant I would go to regularly but occasionally it's fab! The portions are large and the food is generally good. The pig sandwich is my favourite-messy but yummy!   The staff can be a little on the over helpful but at least this means the service tends to be fairly quick.   The noise levels can be pretty horrific when there are large groups in coupled with the loud music.   Not somewhere for an intimate meal but for big portions of good food this is a great place!

MpKs9TAPi5Eh9wYSYtlrZA.text: I don't like the Hard Rock place at all. I have been for a couple of work night outs over the years and have always found it completely under-whelming.   The food is boring and predictable and over priced. The service has always been ok but nothing great. The drinks are fine but never been very impressed with the cocktails.   This place has been going for so long that I would have expected them to have got the formula right by now - maybe that is the problem - it's a tired and jaded formula now. I can see it appealing to small children but not really anyone else!

scyKcvO7HU2UOoR1DAATcA.text: Just another Hard Rock Cafe and it's no better or worse than many of its contemporaries around the globe.   It's set in a nice old bank building on George Street, but that's about as interesting as it gets when you're listening to Billy Joel and munching on your burger with curly fries.   The best thing about this place is probably being able to come here for a late night (over-priced) cocktail. However, if you're coming to Edinburgh, do yourself a favour and go somewhere a bit more extravagant.   I give it two stars because the staff are friendly, the location is good and they make nice cocktails. The rest is just rather dull without being offensive.

UL5vrwItH7o7bVO_9oa1iA.text: I have to say I was very dissapointed here, we waited an hour to be seated, whilst they were quite happy to sell us alcohol, we were then told they thought we had had enough because we had the giggles.   I found the staff to be rude and quite different from what I have come to expect from this food chain who usually go out of the way to give good service.   Found it strange how they didn't think we had had enough for the hour they were taking our money at the bar, and couldn't even be polite about it.   Would never go here again out of principle.

d08MbnXuIgzXEKjcvBbQTQ.text: I have been twice, and the both times I went I enjoyed my meal and the music playing :)   although it's a bit pricey it was worth the money   Oh and their chocolate bownie sunday is to die for and its HUGE! need two people to help finish that.

pfU_iQYUka4tXru6iKIPiw.text: For a chain this was a great experience.   American food outside of America is often kind of gross.  This was decent.   Not excellent but decent.  If this was in the states It May get one less star,  it this one is in Scotland.    The beer selection was underwhelming.  No dark beers on tap.  Out of the darker bottled beers.   Had a "Bourbon" and coke with Jack Daniels.  Jack Daniels isn't technically a bourbon, but close enough.   Also had one of their concoctions.  Was so sweet it should have been a lollipop.    Tried the cauliflower buffalo wings?  Because why not.  It was actually quite good.     The Guinness burger was acceptable.  Good for American food abroad.    My mother's drink was too sweet for her to possibly drink and they took it right off the bill and were very apologetic.     Great staff and management.

o1eZ8P6bD5Ijl8knV2JDcw.text: I only stopped into the Rock Shop on my most recent visit, but I have dined here on previous visits. This is one of the very few Hard Rock Cafes with a classical interior design & stain glass windows, which you don't see in newly opened or redesigned locations. The restaurant had a great atmosphere with plenty of guests on a Saturday late in the afternoon. The Rock Shop was well stocked & I was able to pick up a shot glass & city design bottle opener.

photos.caption: Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. City design magnet bottle opener.
Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Exterior of the restaurant.
Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Stained-glass window with the &#34;Life is lost in dreaming. Dreaming is lost in becoming.&#34; motto.

tpJRodpLi6JIj75_RhHMKg.text: We were only in Edinburgh for the night and we were both sick with the flu.  Food was the last thing we really wanted, but we needed it.  We went for something "standard" that we knew would sit right with us.  Our meals were just fine, the service was attentive...until we paid the bill.  Then, the waiter almost seemed surly and impatient with us.  The table next to us had 10 young women who all got separate tabs and we had to wait a long time for our bill.  So, we felt hustled out when our waiter seemed impatient with us.  All in all, it's clean, familiar, and the food was what we needed.

p0g7QFiuXsN-wWxBqiL9mA.text: Typical hard rock, nothing really special compared to the other 20+ hard rocks Ive been to. When I was  here it wasn't very busy at all so service was quick for a drink anyway. Located not far from Rose street and the Royal Mile is a 10min walk away.

bR2zp8Ew6w0GQaquNkVvkQ.text: This review is solely a review of the rock shop that I visited tonight. I spent $30+ just so I could get a free collectible gift but the blonde lady at the counter had issues with scanning my items and forgot to give me the free collectible item. I had to wait about 15 minutes for a manager to walk her through the transaction. Also disappointed that the restaurant didn't have a sign that said Hard Rock Cafe Edinburgh inside or outside the restaurant.

Z5r7F-ZekniI8IepDkKU4A.text: My bucket list is to attempt to visit all HRC locations!! So, I'm now crossing off Edinburgh location!  Was thrilled to walk in with my family and enjoy the history of the Cafe. HRC is a unique experience for some, you come for the music, appreciate the history and reminisce past visits. Staff was friendly, food is consistent and was thrilled to pick up some classic pins.

photos.caption: Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

H-TEAg-pOS_MTravL27dqg.text: When we first arrived in town we wanted to find the Hard Rock Cafe.  Although a bit pricey for lunch, we really enjoyed our meal and our waiter. We would recommend having lunch or dinner here if you are not on a set budget. Thank you

Z41TVN__3bW57fENC2lQqQ.text: This review is strictly for the bar area and the small shop.  My fiancee has been collecting shot glasses from each Hard Rock that he visits for many years.  So naturally we had to stop at both of the Hard Rock Cafe's in Scotland.  The tradition goes that we order a drink or two and then go to the store to buy our swag.  Our visit to the Hard Rock in Edinburgh wasn't any different.  The bar staff was training new staff so the service was a bit slow, but the bartender made up for that by being very friendly, personable and quick with our drink order once he received it.  There is also WiFi at this location which was great for us since being on WiFi was the only time that are phones would work.  It gave us a chance to check in, find directions and upload a few photos before walking to our next destination.    From there we went up to the store to purchase the shot glasses and a couple of t-shirts.  We're also reward members so we get points for our purchases.  Finally, they also participate in the VAT refund so if your purchase is over 30 BPS, be sure to collect your VAT receipt.

BQTFxDUubOtDmg8p4WScSw.text: Burger and cocktails... That's what I wanted and needed. Nothing else was open so I really had limited choice to quench this craving so I ended up here.   Hard rock is a typical chain but what's cool about this place is that it offers a Scottish burger...pretty touristy but at least they tried eh? The Scottish burger of course has haggis with the typical hamburger ingredient. The best part of the burger was the brown sauce that came with it. I'm not sure what it was or what it's made out of but it went really well with the haggis burger. The chips were blah and the cocktail was ok... Huge portion though! If haggis on your burger isn't your thing, they also have a couple of other burgers that sound pretty decent. In addition to burgers, the menu also have pasta and meat dishes as well as many typical American appetisers.   My friend and I also ended up getting dessert... A big bowl of warm brownies with ice cream. Nothing amazing about this desert other than its size.   The staff is cool and there's free wifi-fi. This place isn't really amazing, and a bit over price. Certainly paying for the name and the big portion, cause it's definitely not the flavour of their dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

xbOgv_ohfFFOt194Rdr2nA.text: Never thought I'd end up here, but I did. We've been with our arabian friends which seemed to make a good impression. The prices are quite high and I was kind of glad I didn't have to pay :D the fish was delicious, but it was so much that I could not finish it at all!  A quite nice restaurant with good service, but there's comparable food for less money!!

qlWre2xpR1bKfoOgmSxTvA.text: I'm not really sure where the hate comes from the Hard Rock Cafe, or other "chain" style restaurants. I've been to my fair share of Hard Rock Cafes (in and out of the U.S.), and I've come to enjoy the consistency, both in customer service and food, that comes from the Hard Rock (or any other chain for that matter).    The Hard Rock in Edinburgh is no different, and suffice it to say, I'm still a fan of the Hard Rock.  My first impression of the Edinburgh Hard Rock was a more intimate restaurant as compared to other Hard Rocks, more of a pub feel.  In contrast, the Hard Rock in Manchester was massive with huge vaulted ceilings.    The food is what you would expect from a Hard Rock, though the Scottish Ale on tap was nice.  I shared the Guinness/Jameson burger with my wife (sorry, 1/2 pound burger by myself doesn't sit well these days), which was outstanding.  I don't even think I said "medium rare", yet my waiter knew.  The burger was juicy, the bun was fresh, and the fixins (lettuce and tomato for those who haven't spent time in the American south) were fresh as well.    I really think the service put the Hard Rock Edinburgh firmly into the 4-star category.  We came on a Tuesday during the dinner rush, yet we were in a seat within 10 minutes and everyone from the hostess, host (took us to our table), and waiter were courteous and attentive.  Throughout the night, our waiter was continuously attentive, kind to our boys, and simply a great waiter (especially during dinner rush).    On a side note, I thought the "high five" thing on Yelp was a little odd (unlocked after you check in).  I would have preferred half off appetizers or something of the sort.

39xZqxTBoUcLKyT13nPOpw.text: Located not too far from the city centre this Hard Rock Cafe definitely got a thumbs up from me. As always the walls were covered in famous musicians instruments and they were playing classic rock music with the matching music videos being shown on multiple screens around the restuarant.   The staff were super friendly and on the ball. We were never sat waiting for too long before someone came over to take our order or to check that things were ok.   The menu is pretty damn big so you may need a while to scan through the pages, especially if you've never been there before. I'd been craving sticky ribs all day, so my food choice was easy - meat duo with ribs and chicken. The BBQ sauce which covered both was absolutely delicious. The only downfall was the coleslaw, however I was so full by that point that I didn't really mind that it wasn't very good. The cowboy beans on the other hand were exceptional (so much so that I'm going to try to replicate them at home sometime soon).  Make sure you're hungry - the portions are more than generous!!

P4pTHc_XNlVgaHK0yZULAw.text: My experience in this hard rock cafe is by far inferior compared to other countries. My recent and (I believe) final visit in Hard Rock Edinburgh was a Saturday afternoon where my friend and I fancied some cocktails along with food so we ended up there (since Fridays have permanently closed). Since we had to wait for our table we decided to had our drinks ordered at the bar: a lime margarita for me and a long island ice tea for my friend. Both standard cocktails to make, yet the bartender failed to do make them good... On the first sip both were tasteless (especially mine).   By this time our table was ready and we moved there, hoping that we could ask our waitress to take care the matter. Our food arrived, yet we weren't asked (as usual) how it was, so we informed our waitress that unfortunately we weren't enjoying our cocktails and we would like to cola colas instead. Yet she didn't express any apology our willingness to resolve this, just asked "so, two cokes?" (for which as expected we were charged on top of the cocktails we left -as you can see in my picture). Usually, in a restaurant that wants to please it costumers they offer to take an item that wasn't satisfying back, offer an alternative or waive the charge to much cheaper options we had to go by. Not at this restaurant... We were really disappointed to choose this place for the cocktails that were such a let down, along with an unhelpful service.

photos.caption: Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Though Hard rock advertises its cocktails, my lime margarita was tasteless. I left it on the table almost full.

fBZTynqPf_u0K2VpHGS-WA.text: Had a burger in here , cant remember what one I got but it was gorgeous, first of all it was huge and the beef was so tender and moist and had the most lovely Smokey flavour, got sauteed mushrooms, Monterey jack cheese and a lovely pepper sauce in the burger , was a lovely burger if not the best burger I've ever had, got chips on the side and they were lovely and crisp , nice flavour too, I would definitely be going back here when I'm in Edinburgh again. Staff were also very friendly and helpful.

JtjjNAazYiUX0NKjA39heA.text: Broke all my rules coming here. Usually avoid chains and especially avoid American chains abroad. But it was cold and rainy in Edinburgh in December (what a surprise!), and I was on a mission to buy a friend a Hard Rock Edinburgh T shirt, so I thought I'd check it out. Given the limited and simplistic menu, and the prices, one would hope they'd go the extra mile to make their simple food special. Nope. To their credit, the hamburger bun was toasted brioche and the hamburger came out hot. The mushrooms were nicely sauteed. However the hamburger was rock hard (methinks machine formed and not enough fat) and cooked well, not medium well as the menu indicated. The Swiss cheese was slapped on and not even melted, making the whole thing fail to gel. The Parmesan fries for a pound extra just had some commercial pre-shredded parmesan dumped on them. Served with plain mayonnaise when a garlic aioli would have been so much better. Edible but with so many great bistros in Georges St, a complete waste of calories.

photos.caption: Photo of Hard Rock Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

ws-uGZt3ClL8VJWu-ri9Ww.text: Hard Rock Edinbugh is a bit like a smaller version of the original in London, it's low-ceilinged and therefore more intimate feeling than most, which is in many ways a good thing. There's strangely a bit of a lack of one of the cornerstones of Hard Rock - memorabilia. It may be because it's one of the older ones, so maybe a refresh is in order. The staff in all HRCs in my experience are great, specifically selected for their sunny disposition which acts as a great antithesis to my own. It's hard not to like them!  We got sat down in one of the booths, ordered my partner's cocktail and my beer and then barely looked at the menu. Why, well cos I almost know it backwards. I went for the Chicken Tenders followed by the Local Legendary Burger, and and my partner went for the Chicken Wings.  The chicken tenders were not bad at all, the batter was just a tiny bit undercooked on the inside but it was crispy on the outside. Just slightly overcrisped for me. The chicken was moist and the dip was nice, well the white one was. I never bother with the red one! The burger though, it was a bit underwhelming, for a start the burger was unexciting and arguably underseasoned, and the "Local" part of the "Local" Legendary Burger was barely discernible. Apparently it's the same as the HRC Glasgow recipe, but it wasn't. There was a fraction of the haggis and none of the whisky sauce. It was still not bad though and yes, the fries were crisp on the outside and fluffy on the inside.  Having been to six Hard Rocks in the last year - Lisbon, Madrid, Glasgow, London, Manchester and now Edinburgh, maybe I'm getting a little jaded! I'm no stranger to the Edinburgh one, but haven't been there for a few years. It was still an above average burger meal, but it failed to hit all the high notes and there's a lot more competition out there now, so out of my six HRC experiences this last year I'm afraid it definitely rates at no. 6.

ElD81Wz4OKW13nLNh66ZHQ.text: Amazing, great food, staff and atmosphere! With iconic music and  rock memorabilia  present throughout, it is my fav dig-out spot in the city. It tends to get very busy at lunch and in the evenings, especially on the weekends so call to book ahead. Most of the staff are very nice although a few are a little slow on English. The manger in very friendly and will help resolve any problems you may have. There is classic music playing 24/7 and you can easily request a favourite song if you want.  The food is priced ok, the average burger is about 14 and desert about 5, although it is great value. I hope this was helpful and you give a visit soon!

QroP4awrgKs18hzaNEipgw.text: There was a time, no so long ago, that HRC was my favourite place in Edinburgh.  However - all that made it great for me then has been surpassed and bettered by other venues and also my taste has changed ever so slightly.   I am fed up with the 'Hi my name is Jack and I will be serving you tonight and I'm so jolly matey and pally you want me to become your bestest friend (for the duration of the meal). It is a way of engaging the customers that I think would befit a 5 year old. How novel and quirky it once was to have the whole restaurant and staff sing Happy Birthday I don't feel like joining in anymore and I cannot be the only one. Taking your 5 year old (or anyone under 18)  to HRC is not the done thing in my book - asking other diners to take a meal break and sing for a party of teens. no, no no .  I don't want to hear an infant crying when Red Hot Chili Peppers are doing their thing or Jimi is stoned on stage - That is my  niggly thing -  how and when did it became OK to bring kids to Hard Rock Cafe?  I am so over the 20 flat screens that are on every wall - that was great in the 90's and early 00's but these days I want to focus on my fellow drinkers / diners or even the food I am eating.  What I really liked about it (and still do) is their burgers, yes they are expensive but they do taste great.  That is it. All other parts of it are now found elsewhere - better.   The Music : great tunes and videos, but the constant assault onto my senses is making me feel dizzy, deaf and old. - I have Spotify at home and my local bar sometimes uses my list - I like that better as I can also talk and be heard. so in that sense it makes HRC redundant. I don't need, (made) to watch videos when I am eating or cocktail drinking.   Oh yes the Cocktails: what a shame - their Purple Haze, Gene Simmons' Bloody Mary and Long Island were staunch favourites, somehow over time they've lost their place on the flavour vs price pole position, as I think for example that The Last Word or  Bar Kohl has an up on that and for similar or cheaper prices and delivering better services.   The Hard Rock Buffalo Wings with a choice of 3 sauces is replaced - by WINGS (with a choice of about 50 sauces)  In the Hard Rock Cafe Shop - you can buy T-shirts and Rock Memorabilia - for a price.  With an HRC loyalty / membership card you get a discount on clothing and meals.  If you are a tourist and you are fine with having to pay a premium for a burger and you are used to the American diner service - HRC is your place. If you are like me and have a little more local knowledge about other places it is easy to go here as a place to meet up first before going somewhere else.

4mePqcO2zoQt6TYhCL_OCQ.text: First of all, I'm excited that this is my first international review.  I'm in Scotland with the fam for ten days and our first stop is Edinburgh.  After way too much flying today (and I still haven't slept more than two hours since leaving LAX on Tuesday), we were hungry. We walked from our hotel to the Hard Rock and there was one bar table open so we hung out there for a few while waiting for our actual dinner table to open up.  It was crowded but our seven person party was nicely accommodated by the staff, who fit in an extra chair for us on a six person table toward the back.    I know the food is at least good, and definitely not bad--I've experienced the Hard Rock twice before (D.C. and Amsterdam!)--but it had been a while. I was actually impressed by my ceasar salad with a good sized piece of salmon on top.  So this is Scotland and therefore I'm not expecting the best food (what can I say, it's the UK--sorry UK friends) and while the salmon wasn't the best I've had, and I'll admit I'm spoiled being from Socal and having a Filipino mother that makes great salmon, it was good and size wise, just what I wanted after my day of travel.  The salad itself was enough for me.    Had I gone with friends I think I would have had more fun, but with the fam I drank water and didn't eat a bunch of fun food. Our server was really nice, very personable, and checking out more rock paraphernalia was awesome.  I think when I was a kid I didn't appreciate the Hard Rock for the times I had been and what it had inside.  Today after my experience I was kind of bummed I didn't end up getting a t-shirt.  Anyway, this makes me want to check out the one in SD when I get home.

_VZfyaULNaUikbLZv-STqQ.text: I got there on a quiet Monday afternoon, in "hungry" mode and was welcomed by a very friendly & chatty front of house dude who guide to my table.  My server Theresa was cool, professional & efficient, she was the only waitress on the floor at time of the day looking after 5 more tables.   I ordered the Santa Fe Spring Rolls stuffed with spinach, black beans, cilantro, corn, jalapenos, diced red peppers and jack cheese + crispy tortilla straws with a side of Hard Rock salsa and guacamole-chipotle ranch dressing . Starter did the trick as it was a crispy, tasty and abundant portion to placate my momentarily ravenous demons.   As a main course I ordered a Top Sirloin Steak medium rare, a cut which in principle was OK, but not properly seared, probably because the grill was not hot enough (should be, for my personal taste, at least 260oC or more) giving the inside of it the texture and flavour of "boiled meat" rather than grilled.   Meal was washed down with a couple of pints of Becks Vier at  3.80 each..still under the 4 quid mark...what a pleasant surprise... All in all a positive experience, place is baby & family friendly, WiFi is available....and the ubiquitous TV plasma screens showing, yeah... you guess it R & R videos. Enjoy your meal!
